userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of U.S. copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provide in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection or tems within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for scholarly research, except where particular restrictions are noted.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The following 9 series are available for research. Missing letters denote closed series.

Series 2 - Richard Allison Files Series 3 - Central Files Series 9 - National Commission on Water Quality Series 10 - New York Office Series 12 - Joseph E. Persico Files Series 13 - Press Releases Series 15 - Speeches Series 18 - Working Papers of the Vice President Series 19 - Foreign Affairs and National Security

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: President Gerald R. Ford nominated Nelson A. Rockefeller to fill the vacant vice presidency following the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon in August 1974. Rockefeller served as Vice President from December 19, 1974, to January 20, 1977.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Repository Name, Collection Name, Record Group Name or Number (if applicable), Series Name or Number (if applicable), Subseries Name or Number (if applicable), Box number, Folder number, specific item description.
Example: Rockefeller Archive Center, Max Bergmann papers, Laboratory Administration, Selective Service Deferments, Box 8, Folder 58, Deferment Policy, May 12, 1941.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into 12 subseries:

Subseries 1 - Presidential Campaign 1976 Subseries 2 - Presidential Panel on Federal Compensation Subseries 3 - Domestic Council Subseries 4 - Energy Independence Authority (EIA) Subseries 5 - Establishment of Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) Subseries 6 - Science Advisory Groups for the Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP Subseries 7 - Administrative and Miscellaneous Files Subseries 8 - VIce Presidential Miscellaneous Files Subseries 9 - STATUS: Monthly Chartbook of Social and Economic Trends, Weekly Meeting with the President Subseries 10 - Chronological Files Subseries 11 - Miscellaneous Clippings Subseries 12 - Productivity Commission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series documents a portion of Nelson A. Rockefeller's public life from 1974 to 1977. Richard Allison was an assistant to Vice President Rockefeller, and these papers constitute background documentation for those files compiled in Record Group 26, Series 18: Working Papers of the Vice President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of correspondence and newspaper clippings pertaining to the 1976 Presidential election. The bulk of the material deals with the 1976 campaign strategy for President Gerald Ford. Notable figures in this subseries are Bob Dole, Jimmy Carter, Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan, and Walter Mondale.

did.unittitle: Delegates and Alternatives for the Republican Convention
The Ford Presidency: "A Portrait of the First Two Years"
National Press Club - Drafts and Arrangements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains memos, materials on meetings, and reports of the Presidential Panel on Federal Compensation, which was established by Presidential Memorandum to recommend appropriate levels of compensation for federal employees in accordance with the principle of comparability with nonfederal employee compensation. The panel was headed by Vice President Rockefeller from June 1975 to December 1975, and it was terminated upon submission of its final report on December 2, 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of memos, background papers, activity reports, and policy reviews of the Domestic Council. The Domestic Council was formed in 1970 on the recommendation of the President's Advisory Council on Executive Organization. Developed as the domestic counterpart to the National Security Council, its major purpose was to create for the President a centralized, comprehensive policy-formulating group that would work closely with the relevant executive departments to analyze and develop policy initiatives on issues such as education, health care, welfare, drug abuse, veteran programs, civil rights, and natural resources.

did.unittitle: Office of Management and Budget (OMB)/Legislative Liaison Meetings
Proposal for a Committee on New York City
Weekly (Periodic) Status Reports to the President

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of correspondence and information on meetings regarding the proposed Energy Independence Authority (EIA). President Gerald Ford submitted legislation proposing the establishment of the EIA on October 10, 1975. The proposal from President Ford was to establish an independent government-owned corporation, managed by a five-member board of directors, with authority to invest a total of $100 billion over a 7-year period in energy projects that would help the United States achieve energy independence. The EIA was to support projects in nuclear energy, solar energy, geothermal energy, and synthetic fuel technology. The legislation was never passed by Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of correspondence and information on meetings of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, which Congress established in 1976 with a broad mandate to advise the President and others within the Executive branch on the impact of science and technology on domestic and international affairs.

did.unittitle: Science Advisory Groups for the Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP)

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains memos and information on meetings with the science advisory groups. Two science advisory groups were appointed by President Ford in November 1975. The first group, chaired by Dr. Simon Ramo, provided advice on the contributions of technology to economic strength. The other group, chaired by Dr. William Baker, provided advice on anticipated advances in science and technology. The groups' priorities were to set up a list of urgent scientific issues. The list included energy, food and nutrition, space, industrial productivity, health and safety regulations, and basic research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged in the original folder order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of miscellaneous files, including vice presidential notes and clippings. It is likely that some of these documents are duplicated in other portions of the vice presidential papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Council of Social Advisors gathered data on social conditions, assessed the effectiveness of existing programs, and developed indicators to measure changes in key social sectors. Its publication, "STATUS," was issued monthly and was available to the general public. This subseries contains general supplemental material on the advisory council on "STATUS."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of memos from Richard Allison to either Nelson Rockefeller or Central Files on various issues.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of magazine and newspaper articles on the vice presidency of Nelson Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of memos and reports of the Productivity Commission, which was established on June 8, 1974, by an act of Congress. Its primary objective was to help increase the productivity of the American economy and to help improve the morale and quality of work of the American worker. The Commission provided technical and advisory assistance to the President and Congress with respect to federal policy affecting productivity and the quality of work.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The records in the Central Files Series are arranged under the following headings:

Name Files, Boxes 70-162. Subject Files, Boxes 163-201. Chronological Files, June 26, 1975 - January 19, 1979, Boxes 39-48, 58-60, 68. Invitations (to speak, appear, attend; most declined), Boxes 19-22, 49-54. Schedules and Invitations (VP activities in the 1976 presidential campaign), Boxes 209-211. Trip files (itineraries, logistics), Boxes 23, 192-197. Speeches, Boxes 189-192. Oversized items sent to the Vice President (books, reports, albums, photos, etc.), Boxes 18, 25-38, 55, 56, 69. Vice President's recommendations for federal appointments (from Richard Allison's files), Boxes 57, 61. Mail Returned by the Secret Service (crank letters), Box 15. Control Slips and Control Cards (carbon copies of routing slips, arranged chronologically), Boxes 212-215, 218-223. Correspondence Form Manual (standard responses to typical letters), Box 224.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Central Files series contains the general correspondence of the Office of the Vice President from Nelson A. Rockefeller's tenure (December 19, 1974, to January 20, 1977). The series offers partial documentation of Rockefeller's role in the development of national policy and his duties as President of the U.S. Senate. There is correspondence with President Gerald R. Ford and members of his staff, congressional representatives, senators, other government officials, and foreign dignitaries. However, there is very little in this series documenting actual policy formation. Much of the correspondence with government officials concerns the Vice President's information-gathering activities on behalf of the White House and executive agencies, as well as his support of the President's policies. There are also reports and position papers on national issues submitted to the Vice President by individuals both within and outside the federal government. Virtually all of these were unsolicited.
Also documented here are Rockefeller's campaign activities on behalf of President Ford and Senator Robert Dole in the 1976 presidential campaign.

The bulk of the correspondence consists of letters from U.S. citizens expressing their opinions on issues, inviting the Vice President to speak at events, asking for autographed photographs of the Vice President, or asking for the his assistance in securing an appointment to a federal agency or a military academy. The responses to such correspondence were written by the Vice President's staff.

Carbon copies of outgoing correspondence are filed in the name, subject, and chronological files. Routine incoming correspondence is filed in the name file, while incoming correspondence of significance was photocopied and filed in both the name and subject files. The chronological file contains only outgoing letters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Folders are rarely in chronological or alphabetical order. For example, the first boxes deal with the closing of the commission. Most boxes seem to be organized according to topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: NOTE TO RESEARCHERS

This series contains the office files of Donna R. Mitchell, a member of Nelson A. Rockefeller's staff. These files document official activities in the execution of her duties as a member of Rockefeller's staff. Unless a document is specifically addressed to or from Nelson A. Rockefeller, or is referred to in a document addressed to him, it should not be assumed he saw the document or was aware of its existence or substance. Furthermore, researchers should bear in mind that staff files may contain documents or drafts addressed to Rockefeller that were never shown to him.
SCOPE AND CONTENT

The National Commission on Water Quality (NCWQ) was formed in1972 by President Richard Nixon, who appointed Nelson A. Rockefeller (then-governor of New York) chair of the Commission. It was an outgrowth of the 1972 Water Pollution Control Act. The Commission got off to a late start: The first meeting was in May 1973. It did not meet its reporting deadline of October 1975 but continued into 1976. The Commission consisted of five members from the public sector and ten from Congress--five each from both chambers. Senator Edmund Muskie and Senator Robert Jones co-chaired the Commission. (Throughout the collection, there is evidence of in-fighting between Rockefeller and Muskie.) The staff of 60 was headed by General Frederick Clarke.

The papers in this collection are those of Donna R. Mitchell. Mitchell, who had been Deputy Director of Rockefeller's Washington office while he was governor of New York, was appointed assistant to the chairman of the NCWQ. She was the key point person between the commission and the staff. She was also Rockefeller's confidential source of information about all aspects of the project as indicated in various memos. (Boxes 21, 22, and 23 contain Mitchell's own reports on New York State Federal Legislation to the Executive Chamber and Albany State Agencies from 1959 to 1967.)

Most significantly, this series consists of hundreds of studies done under contract with outside organizations. The commission spent $11.6 million of its $15 million budget on contracts. The reports cover five broad areas: Technology and Cost Studies (Boxes 31-37); Economic, Social, and Benefit Studies (Boxes 38-42); Environmental Studies (Boxes 42-46); Institutional Studies (Boxes 46-48); and Regional Studies (Boxes 48-53). The material incorporates legal studies of the all-important Public Law 92-500 (the 1972 Amendments to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act). As well, the series contains hundreds of newspaper and magazine clippings covering pollution, industry, treatment centers, water quality, and the politics of the NCWQ.

Additionally, these papers contain Nelson Rockefeller's correspondence with governors, cities, industries, and environmentalists. Boxes 26 and 27 contain Rockefeller's chronological correspondence from 1973 to 1976.

The series also documents the development of the staff's substantial report to the commission (Boxes 14-16, with the final copy in Box 55). The report went through three drafts and then underwent hearings in five major U.S. cities, with Rockefeller presiding over the hearings in Washington, DC (Boxes 17-18). A surprising lacuna of the collection is documentation of the drafting and discussion of the Commission's final report to Congress, which does not appear.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into 3 subseries: Subseries 1: Vice Presidential Confirmation Hearings, 1974 Subseries 2: Office of the Vice President, 1975-1977 Subseries 3: Sound Recordings, 1974-1977

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: When President Gerald R. Ford selected Nelson A. Rockefeller to fill the vacant vice presidency on August 20, 1974, Rockefeller's staff began preparing material for the confirmation hearings. Much of the material in this series was gathered from the Rockefeller family archives, which was located in Rockefeller Center.

Rockefeller's staff spent most of late August and early September preparing background data, developing drafts of testimony, and fulfilling requests for information from Congressional committee members. The files that begin this series are the products of those efforts.

Once he was confirmed and sworn in as Vice President, Rockefeller and his staff began to accumulate files anew. A new set of subject files was created, as well as files concerned with the daily activities of the Vice President. These files were periodically shipped to the family archives in New York for storage.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subseries 1 is arranged alphabetically by topic or person.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files were gathered from the Rockefeller family archives in New York to help prepare testimony and position papers on various issues for the hearings. At the end of each day of testimony, the archive staff gathered information that had been requested that day by the committees and sent it to Washington.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subseries 3 is grouped by format; first, audio cassettes and then reel-to-reel tapes. Each format is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The third subseries is a collection of reel-to-reel audiotapes and audiocassettes. There are two distinct sets of audiocassettes. The first set consists of recordings of the proceedings of the confirmation hearings; the others are cassette recordings of remarks and speeches made by the Vice President. The reel-to-reel audiotapes are recordings of remarks by the Vice President and other dignitaries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into five subseries: Subseries 1 - New York State Committee to Reelect the President Research Files, 1972 Subseries 2 - Miscellaneous Writings, 1971-1974 Subseries 3 - Pre-Vice Presidential Speeches, 1966-1974 Subseries 4 - Press Releases, 1970-1974 Subseries 5 - Miscellaneous Files, 1958-1974

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: NOTE TO RESEARCHERS

This series documents official activities in the execution of Joseph Persico's duties as a member of Nelson A. Rockefeller's staff. The actions, decisions, and exchanges of information or points of view documented here occurred in the course of proposing and implementing policies for the Rockefeller administration, political campaigns, and/or Rockefeller's personal activities. However, unless a document is specifically addressed to or from Nelson Rockefeller, or is referred to in a document addressed to him, it should not be assumed he saw the document or was aware of its existence or substance. Furthermore, researchers should bear in mind that staff files may contain documents or drafts addressed to Rockefeller that were never shown to him.
SCOPE AND CONTENT

This series focuses on Joseph E. Persico's service as the chief speech writer for Nelson A. Rockefeller during his two last terms as Governor of New York (1967-1973) and during his service as Vice President of the United States (1974-1977). This collection contains the speeches and press releases that Persico wrote in this capacity. His personal papers and writings are at the New York State Archives in Albany.

Most of this series is made up of speech files. They contain one or more different versions of each speech: drafts, reading copies, transcripts, or press releases. Drafts and reading copies are likely to include Governor Rockefeller's handwritten changes and notations. Some files contain memos, schedules, or background information on the event at which the speech was given.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joseph E. Persico was born in Gloversville, New York, on July 19, 1930. He graduated from the State University of New York at Albany in 1952 with a B.A. in both English and political science. He then served in the U.S. Navy for three years as a Lt. Junior Grade aboard a minesweeper and at NATO headquarters in Naples, Italy. Returning to the United States in 1954, he matriculated at Columbia University for his graduate work. He received a Ph.D. from the State University of New York at Albany in 1966.

He began his writing career in 1956, serving New York Governor Averill Harriman. In 1959, he became a Foreign Service Officer for the U.S. Information Agency (USIA) in Brazil, Argentina, and Washington, DC. Between 1963 and 1966, he served as executive assistant to New York Health Commissioner Hollis Ingraham.
From 1966 to 1974, Persico was Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's chief speech writer and remained in that position during Rockefeller's vice presidency.

Persico's first book, published in 1977, was "My Enemy, My Brother," a history of the Battle of Gettysburg. In 1982, Persico published a biography of Nelson Rockefeller, "The Imperial Rockefeller." More recently, Persico collaborated with Colin Powell on his biography and wrote a book on Franklin Roosevelt, "Roosevelt's Secret War: FDR and World War II Espionage."

did.unittitle: New York State Committee to Reelect the President Research Files

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by state.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files contain statistical data and factual information for each U.S. state, including facts on population, polls, state organizations, industry, and key individuals in state governments. These statistics and facts were used by the Committee to Reelect the President research staff based in New York.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains miscellaneous speeches and transcribed recorded presentations that Governor Rockefeller gave at various functions and locations. The speeches appear in other parts of this collection but were grouped as miscellaneous writings for no specific reason.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries is composed of the speeches written by Joseph Persico for Governor Rockefeller during his third and fourth gubernatorial terms. It also includes speeches written during Rockefeller's first congressional confirmation hearing for U.S. Vice President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a collection of press releases, which includes transcripts of interviews, press conferences, and speeches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Nelson Rockefeller's quotations on major issues, an article for the American Academy of Political and Social Science on revenue sharing, program papers on topics such as aging and the economy, and subject indices for speeches.

scopecontent.p: Excerpts from speeches and statements by NAR as Governor, as Chair of the Commission on Critical Choices for Americans, and as the National Commissioner on Water Quality.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains press releases, notes, and background information on the statements and activities of Vice President Rockefeller. Also included are trip itineraries and correspondence regarding the logistics of vice presidential travel.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into two parts: Subject Files (Folders 1-382)--and Chronological Files (Folder 383-805).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Broad topics covered include national politics, government, public policy issues, and U.S. foreign relations. Many files include drafts of speeches.

did.unittitle: Working Papers of the Vice President

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Over the course of Nelson Rockefeller's tenure as Vice President of the United States, he served on several commissions, including the National Commission on Water Quality. Vice President Rockefeller also served as chair of the Domestic Council. The majority of Rockefeller's actions as Vice President are documented in this series of 63 volumes. They contain schedules, agenda and minutes of meetings, position papers, and memoranda and correspondence generated as part of the Vice President's daily activities.

Volumes 9 through 20 focus on Rockefeller's involvement with President Ford's Domestic Council, while documentation of the Vice President's meeings with President Ford are in Volumes 27 through 31. Volumes 50 through 60 contain press materials issued by the VP's office and transcripts of Rockefeller's speeches, television appearances, press conferences, as well as statements and press releases issued by his office. Of particular note in Volume 32 is documentation of the fiscal crisis that affected New York City and State. The majority of the information was provided by T. Norman Hurd, Special Assistant to Vice President Rockefeller. While Rockefeller was Governor of New York, Hurd served successively as Budget Director, Director of State Operations, and Secretary to the Governor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Information on the disposition of the Vice President's papers at the conclusion of his tenure and plans for relocation to archival locations. Advance Plans. Central Files - Summary (correspondence). Central Files - Notes. Central Files - Name File (sender/addressee). Central Files - Subject File. Howe Files (Classified Files). Kightliner (photographer) Mrs. Rockefeller. Pagnotta, Frank R. (Personnel). Pagnotta, Frank R. (VP Personal). Pagnotta, Frank R. (Other - VP Administrative). Pagnotta, Frank R. (Gift) (tab only). Speeches (to 1974). Speeches (1975+). Press Releases. Secretariat/Allison. Allison/Notebooks. Allison/File Folders. Secretariat/Briefing Notes. Secretariat/Herter, Huldrum, Towell. Spoff. Wallison, Peter. Water Quality.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller served as the second unelected Vice President in the history of the United States. (President Gerald Ford, whom Rockefeller served as Vice President, had been the first unelected Vice President.) Although Mr. Rockefeller acted relatively extensively in the areas of foreign relations and national security, his main focus, in the view of many observers, was on domestic policy. At the same time, the work that commanded the greatest public attention during the Ford-Rockefeller Administration was that of the CIA Commission. The recommendations issued by the commission strongly affected the policy and operation of the CIA for a generation.

Jonathan T. Howe graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1957 and earned a Ph.D. from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Tufts University in 1969. His early career in the Navy was spent on submarines. Prior to serving with Vice President Rockefeller, he was on the National Security Council staff as military assistant to the Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, 1969 to 1974. Later appointments included senior military assistant to the Deputy Secretary of Defense, 1981 to 1982; Assistant to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, 1987 to 1989; and Deputy Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, 1991 to 1993. He also served in Somalia as the Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General, 1993 to 1994, and after retirement from the Navy, he ran a philanthropic foundation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The arrangement of the series, while mainly by broad topic, is inconsistent on occasion. However, the folder order has been kept intact to maintain a direct correlation to the separated, classified pages. For this same reason, there are no Folders 122 to 192.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: RESTRICTIONS

Several files and individual pages in this series are closed. See the folder list for details. In accordance with Archive Center policy, correspondence with or substantively about living members of the Rockefeller family is closed. The exception is reference to Margaretta (Happy) Rockefeller in her official capacity as wife of the Vice President. Additionally, material bearing a U.S. government security classification is closed.
NOTE TO RESEARCHERS

This series contains documents that were declassified by the U.S. government during a review by government officials at the Archive Center from 2003 to 2006. Any document that remains classified since the review has been removed from its folder and replaced with a separation sheet to note its original and current locations. Therefore, all materials in the open folders is now declassified, whether or not the classification stamps on them indicate otherwise. Almost all of the declassified documents prominently display a federal agency's declassification stamp and date.

The original title of this series was Foreign Policy and Travel. It was changed during the archival processing to Foreign Affairs and National Security to more accurately reflect the contents of the folders. However, the original title may appear on separation sheets and other processing-related documents.
SCOPE AND CONTENT

The bulk of this series of papers consists of files kept by Captain Jonathan T. Howe, Assistant to the Vice President for National Security Affairs, who served Nelson A. Rockefeller during his entire vice presidency (December 19, 1974 to January 20, 1977) in the Gerald R. Ford Administration. The contents reflect international relations and national security topics that Capt. Howe monitored closely for the Vice President. He also oversaw Mr. Rockefeller's appointment schedule on these matters and coordinated with Peter Wallison, Counsel to the Vice President, on suggested responses to inquiries involving foreign officials or national security issues.

The topics covered include International Travel, National Security, Meetings with Foreign Dignitaries, Meetings with U.S. Officials, the Commission on the Organization of the Government for the Conduct of Foreign Policy (Murphy Commission), Intelligence, Countries/Regions, and the Commission on CIA Activities Within the United States (alternately Rockefeller or CIA Commission). Additionally, there are several folders of background information on the Operations Coordinating Board, which originate from Mr. Rockefeller's tenure as Special Assistant to President Eisenhower during the mid-1950s. Also significant in this series are monthly folders of Captain Howe's chron file. (See topic descriptions below.)

Noticeably absent is documentation of direct communication between the Vice President and President Ford on any of these matters. However, there are numerous memos throughout the series from Secretary of State Henry Kissinger--particularly under International Travel--and National Security Affairs Assistant Brent Scowcroft--particularly under National Security Council Meetings.

The arrangement of the series, while mainly by broad topic, is inconsistent on occasion. However, the folder order has been kept intact to maintain a direct correlation to the separated, classified pages. For this same reason, there are no Folders 122 to 192.

Additionally, some folder numbers use a decimal extension (for example, Folder 13.1, Folder 336.4). This designation can mean that either it is a folder created to subdivide an overfilled original folder or it is a closed folder of restricted documents. The latter are prominently labeled as such in the folder list.
DESCRIPTION

International Travel (Folders 1-57) ranges from the Vice President serving as the official U.S. representative at funerals of foreign dignitaries or national celebrations to meetings with heads of state or their top ministers. In 1976 he attended several international celebrations to commemorate the U.S. Bicentennial. Some personal travel files exist as well. Every trip includes a substantial amount of U.S. State Department cables, itineraries, background information on the countries being visited, cultural protocol tips, and follow-up correspondence.

National Security folders are scattered throughout the series but include titles such as National Security Council Meetings, Defense Department Briefings, Cruise Missiles, and Pertinent National Security Developments. Intelligence-related folders also crop up sporadically; Intelligence Review and Reorganization, President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB), and Terrorism are a few title examples.

Meetings with Foreign Dignitaries (Folders 64-88) include arrangements, agenda, and either notes or verbatim accounts of the discussions. They are arranged by mouth in roughly reverse chronological order. Meetings with U.S. Officials (Folders 93-97) have similar contents but are less numerous. They too are arranged in roughly reverse chronological order. See the Materials of Special Significance section for specific names and dates of significant meetings with those officials.

In January 1975, President Ford recommended that Vice President Rockefeller fill an open seat on the Commission on the Organization of the Government for the Conduct of Foreign Policy, more commonly referred to as the Murphy Commission. The commission was established by an act of Congress in June 1972, and it concluded its work in June 1975. Capt. Howe often sat in for the Vice President at the commission meetings. Folders 103-121 hold correspondence, agenda, report drafts, press clippings, and meeting minutes. Folder 120 contains a thorough summary of the history of the commission, including a candid memo on its workings and aftermath written by Capt. Howe to Mr. Rockefeller in January 1977.

Additionally, the contents of more than 30 binders of working papers and background information on the Murphy Commission are at the end of this series in Folders 393-429. Items labeled Books directly correlate to commission meetings during the Vice President's tenure. A tab-level listing of their contents is provided. Items labeled Background Workbooks are background materials from meetings in 1973 and 1974, prior to Mr. Rockefeller's membership on the commission. There is no tab-level listing for them, but the folders are grouped by topic (e.g., intelligence, internationals economics). Lastly, the eight-volume set of the published final report of the Murphy Commission (1 report volume and 7 appendices) has been removed from this series and added to the RAC library collection (library catalog #353.001 COM).

Folders 232-284 cover issues on specific countries/regions, from Angola to Yugoslavia. These files may contain duplicates of documents found under International Travel but often have unique ones. They are arranged in semi-alphabetical order by country name.

Captain Jon Howe's Chron Files (Folders 314-320.5 and 333-344) are an informative source on both the daily activities of the Office of the Vice President and the significant national and international events during those years. They are arranged by month in approximate reverse chronological order. A few reference files are interspersed among them.

In December 1974 at President Ford's request, Nelson Rockefeller became chair of the newly appointed Commission on CIA Activities Within the United States, which was established by Executive Order as a result of ongoing claims of abuse of jurisdiction against the federal agency. The commission, which came to be known as both the Rockefeller Commission and the CIA Commission, is documented from its inception to its final report in Folders 322-332.2 and 346-392. Also among these files are Cold War-era materials from the Operations Coordinating Board that contain information on studies on psychological warfare, Soviet military capabilities, and the Quantico Panel from 1953 to 1955. They are all contemporaneous with Mr. Rockefeller's service in President Eisenhower's Administration as Special Assistant to the President for Foreign Affairs.
MATERIALS OF SPECIAL SIGNIFICANCE

Numerous folders in this series contain materials of special significance for research on Nelson Rockefeller as Vice President, on national intelligence, and on international affairs during the mid-1970s.

One distinction from other series in the Nelson A. Rockefeller Papers is that these records contain copious amounts of handwritten notes by the Vice President. In particular, refer to Folder 121, NAR Notes on Murphy Commission, 1975; Folder 327, CIA Commission, NAR's Handwritten Notes, 1975; Folder 350, Memo to President from Donald Rumsfeld on CIA Directorship, June 1975; Folders 352 to 353.1, NAR Drafts to CIA Commission Report Chapters, May 1975; and Folders 393 to 420, Murphy Commission Books I-XXVIII.

There is substantial content on meetings between Vice President Rockefeller and foreign or U.S. officials, including some verbatim accounts. Documentation on meetings with foreign dignitaries, U.S. Defense Department officials, and other U.S. officials are organized by month in Folders 64 to 97. Memoranda of conversations are grouped by year in Folders 98 to 100.1. While this arrangement does not enumerate the names of these people, the following alphabetical list provides dates of meetings between the Vice President and these heads of state and other significant officials:

George H. W. Bush, CIA Director, March 1976 President Valerie Giscard D'Estaing of France, March 1976 General Alexander Haig, NATO Commander, November 1975 and May 1976 Emperor Hirohito of Japan, October 1975 King Hussein of Jordan, April 1975 King Juan Carlos of Spain, November 1975 King Khalid and Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia, March 1975 Henry Kissinger, Secretary of State (see folders on International Travel and Countries and Folders 213-215.1) Reza Shah Pahlavi of Iran, May 1975 and March 1976 (see also Folder 241) Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, September 1974 and January 1976 President Anwar Sadat of Egypt, March and October 1975 Brent Scowcroft, Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs (see folders on NSC Meetings, 1975-1977) Senator Tran Van Lam of the Republic of Viet Nam, February 1975 U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, April 1976 Paul A. Volcker, economic consultant, May 1975 Kurt Waldheim, UN Secretary-General, June 1975 Prime Minister Harold Wilson of the United Kingdom, January, July, September 1975

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers may also wish to consult other portions of the Nelson A. Rockefeller (NAR) Papers, in particular Group 4: NAR Personal, Series O: Washington, DC, Subseries 7: Special Assistant to the President for Foreign Affairs for additional materials on the Operations Coordinating Board from the 1950s. Also, in Record Group 26: NAR Vice Presidential, refer to Series 3: Central Files, Series 13: Press Releases, Series 15: Speeches, and Series 18: Working Papers of the Vice President.

Tab A - Memorandum for the Vice President (Basic memo from Book 22) Tab A1 - Multilateral Diplomacy and Global Issues Tab B - Human Rights, Humanitarian, and Ethical Considerations in the Conduct of Foreign Policy Tab C - U.S. Policies on Human Rights and Authoritarian Regimes Tab D - Public Diplomacy Tab E - Stanton Panel on USIA Tab F - A Critique of the Stanton Report on Information, Education and Cultural Relations Tab G - Abbott Washburn comments on Stanton Panel Recommendations Tab H - George Meany letter on USIA Tab I - Statement of Director, USIA before Committee on Foreign Relations, U.S. Senate Tab J - Statement of Frank Stanton before Senate Foreign Relations Committee

Tab A - Memorandum for the Vice President on May 27 meeting. Tab B - Intelligence Issues Requiring Commission Decision Tab C - Commission Discussion of "Central Structure for Policy Integration" Tab D - State Department and White House Organization Tab E - Alternative Patterns of White House Organization Tab F - Outline of Commission's Final Report Tab G - Executive Agreements and Executive Privilege Tab H - Draft Vice Presidential letter to Commissioner Murphy on Executive Agreements and Executive Privilege Tab I - Murphy memo for Commissioners on Intelligence and White House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Additional items for June 3 meeting. Casey views on White House Organization and Casey and Murphy views on Intelligence. Wallison argument against Creation of a Separate Director of National Intelligence. Draft of Dissenting Report.

Tab A - Agenda for June 3 Meeting Tab B - Organization for Foreign Affairs Tab C - Murphy Memo on Intelligence Tab C1 - Murphy Memo on White House Organization Tab D - Wallison Memo on Murphy Commission (National Intelligence) Tab E - Dissenting Opinion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on previous meeting. Topics discussed were Executive-Congressional Relations, White House Economic Structure, and Stanton Recommendations Concerning USIA.

Tab A - Executive-Congressional Relations Tab B - Attorney General Levi letter to Vice President on Executive Privilege and Executive Agreements Tab C - Discussion Paper on Organizing for Foreign Economic Policy Tab D - Draft Commission Report on USIA and VOA (Broomfield comments) Tab E - Draft Supplementary Opinion
